title: The Best And Worst Shoulder Exercises

S-Tier.setup_notes: Set the cable at around hand height.
S-Tier.execution_notes: Raise the cable out to the side, ensuring your arm and the cable form a 90째 angle for maximum tension.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: Provides maximum tension on the side delt while it's most stretched, feels excellent, and allows for even tension throughout the range of motion.
S-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Lateral head of the deltoid, due to the 90째 angle tension.
S-Tier.alternative_options: Can use wrist cuffs for better focus on delts.
S-Tier.additional_notes: Favorite side delt exercise, making it the second reveal behind door number two.

S-Tier.execution_notes: Sweep the cable up, out, and back.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: Provides a bigger range of motion and excellent tension.
S-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Lateral head of the deltoid, due to the sweeping motion.
S-Tier.limitations: Some may find it awkward to learn.
S-Tier.additional_notes: Not the number one pick due to learning curve.

S-Tier.exercise_name: Behind the Back Cuffed Lateral Raise
S-Tier.setup_notes: Hook wrists into cuffs, optionally grab lacrosse balls, step over one cable, spin around, cross cables behind back, step forward.
S-Tier.execution_notes: Raise cables out and slightly forward.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: Allows both arms to work simultaneously, doubling time efficiency.
S-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Lateral head of the deltoid, due to simultaneous arm movement.

S-Tier.execution_notes: Cross arms over at the top, sweep cables out rather than yanking back.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: Provides an amazing stretch and even tension throughout the range.
S-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Posterior head of the deltoid, due to the sweeping motion.
S-Tier.alternative_options: Alternate which arm crosses over on top to avoid imbalances.
S-Tier.additional_notes: Number one rear delt builder, third reveal behind door number three.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Lean against a bench or rack.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Perform lateral raise with dumbbells while leaning.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Modifies resistance curve to place more tension on side delt when stretched.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Lateral head of the deltoid, due to modified resistance curve.
A-Tier.scientific_insights: Study suggests emphasis shift from rotator cuff to lateral delt.

A-Tier.execution_notes: Press dumbbells overhead, allowing them to converge at the top.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Faster setup than barbell, more range of motion, more side delt involvement.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Anterior and lateral heads of the deltoid, due to pressing motion.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Find a machine that allows a deep stretch.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Press using the machine, focusing on a deep stretch.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Feels better than dumbbells, less technique-dependent, allows failure without losing control.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Anterior head of the deltoid, due to pressing motion.
A-Tier.additional_notes: Personal favorite, number one exercise for front delts, first reveal behind door number one.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Lie on your side against a bench.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Perform lateral raise while lying on your side.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: High tension while delts are stretched, stable position, large range of motion.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Lateral head of the deltoid, due to sidelying position.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Set up the rope a little lower.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Take an underhand grip, externally rotate shoulders as you pull.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Targets rear delts well, provides a big stretch, solid for overload.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Posterior head of the deltoid, due to pulling motion.

B-Tier.execution_notes: Raise dumbbells to the side until arms are at 90째.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Time efficient, proven to grow shoulders, but suboptimal tension curve.
B-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Lateral head of the deltoid, due to lateral raise motion.
B-Tier.limitations: Zero tension at the bottom, peak tension at 90째.
B-Tier.alternative_options: Lean against something to modify resistance curve.

B-Tier.execution_notes: Perform lateral raise with a focus on full contraction.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Fully contracts side delt, but same resistance curve issues as standard lateral raise.
B-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Lateral head of the deltoid, due to full contraction.
B-Tier.limitations: Same resistance curve issues as standard lateral raise.

B-Tier.tier_reasons: High tension in stretch, good overload, gratifying lift, but anterior delt dominant and less stable.
B-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Anterior head of the deltoid, due to pressing motion.
B-Tier.additional_notes: Overhated by science crowd, overrated by barbell crowd.

B-Tier.execution_notes: Perform lateral raise using the machine.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Consistent tension, but higher pads may not feel as good.
B-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Lateral head of the deltoid, due to machine lateral raise motion.
B-Tier.limitations: Moment arm to shoulder is short, may crank shoulders.

B-Tier.setup_notes: Preferably use cables with a rope.
B-Tier.execution_notes: Sweep handles out as you row.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Targets upper traps and side delts, but traps may take over.
B-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Trapezius and lateral head of the deltoid, due to rowing motion.

B-Tier.execution_notes: Perform reverse fly with dumbbells while bent over.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Good option if no cables, but zero tension at the bottom.
B-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Posterior head of the deltoid, due to reverse fly motion.
B-Tier.additional_notes: Rear delts often get sore from these.

C-Tier.execution_notes: Perform lateral raise using a band.
C-Tier.tier_reasons: Provides zero tension in the stretch, maximum tension at the top.
C-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Lateral head of the deltoid, due to band resistance.
C-Tier.alternative_options: Dumbbells, cables, or machine laterals are better choices.

D-Tier.tier_reasons: Redundant if pressing is included in the program.
D-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Anterior head of the deltoid, due to front raise motion.
D-Tier.additional_notes: Can be useful for those with underdeveloped anterior delts or who can't press.

criterias.High Tension in Stretched Position: The exercise should provide significant tension when the muscle is in its most stretched position, which is crucial for muscle growth.

criterias.Feel Good: The exercise should not cause shoulder pain and should have a smooth resistance profile.

criterias.Simple Progression: The ability to easily add weight or reps over time to ensure continuous muscle growth.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.Anterior Deltoid: Raises the arm up to the front.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.Lateral Deltoid: Lifts the arm out to the side.

main_knowledge_summary.form_details: For lateral raises, leaning against a bench can modify the resistance curve to place more tension on the side delts when stretched. Using cables at hand height provides maximum tension on the side delts when stretched. For overhead presses, seated variations offer more stability, and using dumbbells allows for a greater range of motion and more side delt involvement.
main_knowledge_summary.training_keys: Focus on exercises that provide high tension in the stretched position for optimal hypertrophy. For side delts, prioritize exercises like cable lateral raises and behind-the-back cuffed lateral raises. For front delts, machine shoulder presses are recommended. Rear delts benefit from reverse cable crossovers and reverse pec deck exercises.
main_knowledge_summary.research_insights: The video mentions that the trend in current evidence suggests the stretch is more important than the squeeze for muscle growth, although there is little direct evidence on shoulders. Real-world examples show bodybuilders achieving significant growth with exercises like dumbbell lateral raises despite suboptimal tension curves.
main_knowledge_summary.optimization_notes: To optimize shoulder workouts, incorporate exercises that target each deltoid head effectively. Use machines or cables for consistent tension and stability. Consider using wrist cuffs for cable exercises to enhance focus on the delts. Avoid redundant exercises like front raises if pressing movements are already included in the program.
